    Corrections and systematic uncertainties

    The goal of our measurement is as follows: we want to compare our simulation - including tt¯ signal and background - to our data, and from the differences infer the tt¯ cross section. The way of doing this will be the topic of Exercise 4.

    However, in order for this to work (and not mistake some miscalibrations for physics effects), we need to get our simulation as correct as possible, and then quantify the remaining uncertainties. Unfortunately, the simulation as we get it out of the box is not quite accurate enough for this: we need correction factors.

    Correction factors

    In CMS, most correction factors are centrally provided in some form - you may have encountered them in the short exercises. Of course, this is still an "early" measurement on "new" data, so not all of them are available yet, but for now, let us not be concerned with that.

    As an example, let us look at lepton scale factors we mentioned earlier. The point of these is to compensate for the fact that the lepton efficiency - that is, the probability to correctly reconstruct and identify a lepton from its signature in the detector - is not exactly the same in data and simulation. As a result, the number of events passing the "exactly two leptons" requirement will be different, leading to a disagreement.

    For this analysis, the lepton scale factors are contained in ROOT files located in the inputs/2022/leptons folder. For technical reasons, the muon scale factors are split into two steps (reconstruction and identification), while these are combined for electrons.

    Question

    Open one of the scale factor files with either ROOT or uproot and look at the 2D histograms contained within (you can use whatever plotting / visualization tool you like). Can you guess what the relation of the three histograms is? Which one of these is needed to correct the simulation?

    Now, let us look at how these are handled in Pepper.

    Question

    Open the file pepper/processor_basic.py and look at the compute_lepton_sf function. Currently, only the electron scale factors are implemented.

    Try to understand how the code works! After retrieving the scale factors from the config, Pepper helpfully transforms them into functions that you can easily apply - you just need to pass the correct variables. You can also look at the main config (config_ttxs_dilep.hjson) to see how the scale factors are referenced there.

    There is also a bit about systematic uncertainties. We will come to that later in this exercise.

    To-do

    Implement also the muon reconstruction and identification scale factors, following the example of the electron scale factors! For now, you can ignore the systematic uncertainties.

    Note that they are a function of the muon pT and |η|. The two different scale factors are independent and should be multiplied with each other.

    As always, if you are done, run in debug mode to test.

    Introduction to systematic uncertainties

    In HEP, we typically split the uncertainties on our results into two parts: a statistical and a systematic part. The statistical uncertainty is easy to grasp (though not always easy to calculate): Our data is, in essence, a gigantic counting experiment, and so our data comes with an inherent randomness. In the plots you have made so far, the statistical uncertainty is included as the error bars on the black dots representing the data.

    The systematic uncertainty, by contrast, represents our incomplete knowledge of the modeling of our experiment - that is, in this case, of our Monte Carlo simulation. It is usually a lot less clear-cut than the statistical uncertainty, since estimating it requires a judgement call from us as analyzers on how sure we are of our prediction. There is often not one "correct" way of doing so; however; in CMS there are some official recommendations for the most common sources.

    We can roughly split the different sources of systematic uncertainty in three categories: Theoretical uncertainties, which come from shortcomings and incompleteness of our theory predictions; Experimental uncertainties, which come from imperfect understanding and/or modeling of the different components of the CMS detector, as well as the reconstruction of the detector output; and uncertainties from the Monte Carlo statistics, which come from the finite number of events that make up our MC simulation, limited by our computational power.

    Some of these uncertainties will only affect the total number of predicted events, such as e.g. the uncertainty on the luminosity. Most, however, will in addition also influence the shape of the histograms. We estimate those uncertainties by deriving alternative histograms, representing a 1σ shift of the corresponding uncertainty. In Exercise 4, we will then use these histograms to include the uncertainties in the fit of the cross section.

    Systematics in Pepper

    If you look at the config hjson file, you will find an option compute_systematics that will be set to false. This is a general flag enabling computation of any implemented systematics during the processing.

    To-do

    Change the value of compute_systematics to true and re-run Pepper in debug mode.

    Open one of the resulting histograms in the Python interpreter, and see what changed. Try to get a list of all systematics currently included - can you guess what some of them mean?

    Note that, in general, enabling the computation of systematics will slow down the analysis.

    Let us now look at a piece of code to see how systematic uncertainties are defined. As an example, we will use the uncertainty in the lepton scale factors that we have already looked at in Exercise 2.

    Question

    Go back to the function compute_lepton_sf in pepper/processor_basic.py and look at the part concerning systematics in the electron scale factors (i.e. the code starting with if self.config["compute_systematics"]:). Try to understand how setting systematics works!

    To-do

    Implement systematics on the lepton scale factors also for the muon scale factors that you implemented in Exercise 2.

    Further systematics

    There are some more additional systematics that we would like to implement, constituting the remainder of this exercise. You are encouraged to split the work on this and work e.g. in teams of two or three. If all teams are done, make sure to share the work you did with the others! You should also try to combine the results of the two teams into one (if you know how to do this, you can use git for this purpose - but copying code is also fine for now).

    Project #1: Parton shower uncertainties

    Parton showers are one part in the tool chain for simulating our physical predictions. They describe, in essence, the splitting of coloured particles of high energy into jets composed of many color-neutral particles of lower momentum. This is formally described by QCD; however, since QCD at low energy scales is non-perturbative, a parton shower by necessity has heuristic elements, the details of which might be uncertain.

    In the MC samples used here, the parton showering was done with the program Pythia 8. This program allows for an estimation of the parton shower uncertainty by varying the energy scales at which the computations in the shower are performed. We will here consider two different energy scales: μISR for initial state radiation, meaning gluons or quarks emitted from the partons in the initial state; and μFSR for final state radiation, i.e. gluons or quarks emitted from the particles in the final state (e.g. the top quarks in tt¯).

    Lucky for us, we do not need to concern ourselves with the actual workings of Pythia, since CMS has done it for us already and the required information is available in our nanoAOD files. They come in the form of weights - in order to get from the nominal prediction (i.e. both scales at their default values) to the varied one (e.g. μFSR increased by a factor of two), we simply need to weight our events with the corresponding weight factor.

    Question

    Look at the nanoAOD auto-documentation here and search for the branch PSWeight. You should see a very brief documentation of what this branch contains. It is somewhat cryptic - can you make sense of it?

    It might also be helpful to open a nanoAOD file (e.g. from the TTTo2L2Nu_CP5_13p6TeV_powheg-pythia8 dataset) in either ROOT or uproot - whatever you are more comfortable with - and look at the contents of the PSWeight branch.

    To-do

    Implement the parton shower uncertainties in Pepper!

    There is already a dummy function in pepper/processor_basic.py that you can use, called add_ps_uncertainties. You can roughly follow these steps:

    • Retrieve the PSWeight branch from the data;
    • Using the information from the documentation, disentangle the weights for FSR and ISR uncertainties, and identify the up and down parts;
    • Set the systematics in the Pepper processor by calling the function selector.set_systematic("syst_name", weights_up, weights_down).

    If you are done, run first with debug to see if there is an error, and inspect an output histogram to make sure that your new systematics are there. If it looks good, run on the full dataset and make control plots. Do you see any difference to the control plots made in Exercise 2?

    Project #2: Pileup reweighting

    In a LHC collision, there are much more than two protons involved: in addition to the interaction producing the process we are interested in, e.g. tt¯, there will also always be lower-energy interaction of other protons in the colliding bunches, which will usually result in hadronic activity (i.e. jets). These additional jets in an event are collectively referred to as pileup.

    In our simulation, we model pileup simply by mixing additional interactions into the events. However, we do not know the true distribution of the number of interactions per event at the time of generating the MC simulation - this is especially true for an early measurement such as this one, where the generation happened before the actual data taking. Instead, we will go for an experimental reweighting approach to correct the simulation.

    Question

    Start by looking at the control plots you did in the previous exercises for the following variable:

    • pileup_nvtx: The number of good reconstructed primary vertices
    • pileup_rho_calo: The mean energy density ρ in the calorimeters
    • pileup_rho_tracker: The mean energy density ρ in the tracker

    All three are proxies for the true number of interactions (which we can of course not measure directly in the data). What do you see in the plots? What does that say about the quality of the pileup modeling in the simulation?

    To correct the pileup distribution, we will employ a simple one-dimensional histogram reweighting - that is, we simply weight each MC event by the ratio of data to simulation of the plots you just looked at. Simple, right?

    To-do

    Derive a pileup reweighting scale factor and save it as a ROOT file!

    Pick one of the three pileup variables you want to use for your reweighting. You can work in Python or ROOT as you prefer. Again, there are some rough steps to follow:

    • Open the corresponding histogram .coffea file in an interpreter or notebook (if you use ROOT, you need to convert it first).
    • Split the histogram into a histogram containing the data and one containing the simulation. Sum both histograms over all datasets.
    • Calculate the ratio of the data and the simulation histogram. but BE CAREFUL-- before you divide, normalize the two histograms to have the same integral. Otherwise, you would be changing the event yield of your simulation!
    • Save the ratio as a 1D histogram to a ROOT file.

    Now, on towards the implementation in Pepper!

    Note that, technically, we will implement this as a cut in pepper even though no events get actually cut away: the syntax used for cuts is just as suited to applying per-event level weights, which is what we want to do here.

    To-do

    Implement pileup reweighting in the form of an additional cut in pepper!

    • Copy your scale factor ROOT file somewhere within the inputs/2022 directory.
    • In the config, find the commented out line specifying pileup_reweighting_exp. Uncomment it and point it to your file.
    • Create a new method in processor_ttxs_dilep.py for the pileup reweighting. You can receive a callable object for your scale factors with sffunc = self.config["pileup_reweighting_exp"]. Orient yourself by the lepton scale factors you implemented earlier on how to calculate the weights.
    • Do not forget to add the new cut in the main process_selection method.

    If you are done, run first with debug and then on the full dataset. Confirm using the control plots that the reweighting works!

    If you are really fast, you can also think about how to define and implement a systematic uncertainty on the pileup reweighting.
